DataElement.preferredDefinition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics related to a functional test.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to a functional test._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to a functional test.

Concepts.definition: A subject domain utilized for the submission of information encompassing and representing data, vocabulary or records related to a functional test.

Property.preferredDefinition: This term is used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

ValueDomain.preferredName: CDISC Functional Test Category Terminology Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Terminology associated with the functional test domain categories of the Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) Standard Data Tabulation Model (SDTM)._A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Timed Up and Go Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Timed Up and Go Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed by Mathias et al in 1986 which is used to test basic mobility skills in frail elderly persons and other populations such as people with arthritis, stroke, and vertigo. This functional test measures the time in seconds for a person to stand up from a standard armchair, walk 3 meters, turn, walk back to the chair, and sit down again. Scoring of this test is based on the average of multiple completed and timed trials.

Concepts.longName: Timed Up and Go Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed by Mathias et al in 1986 which is used to test basic mobility skills in frail elderly persons and other populations such as people with arthritis, stroke, and vertigo. This functional test measures the time in seconds for a person to stand up from a standard armchair, walk 3 meters, turn, walk back to the chair, and sit down again. Scoring of this test is based on the average of multiple completed and timed trials.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Trail Making Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Trail Making Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A neuropsychological test of visual attention and task switching that requires a subject to connect a sequence of 25 consecutive targets. It provides an easy to administer and reliable assessment of attention, sequencing, cognition, visual search, and motor function.

Concepts.definition: A neuropsychological test of visual attention and task switching that requires a subject to connect a sequence of 25 consecutive targets. It provides an easy to administer and reliable assessment of attention, sequencing, cognition, visual search, and motor function.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Timed 25-Foot Walk Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Timed 25-Foot Walk Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed to measure walking ability through gait speed. This functional test is a quantitative mobility and leg function performance test where a study subject is asked to walk 25 feet from a marked starting point. The time is calculated from the initiation to the end of walking when the patient has reached the 25-foot mark. Scoring of this test is based on the average of two completed trials.

Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed to measure walking ability through gait speed. This functional test is a quantitative mobility and leg function performance test where a study subject is asked to walk 25 feet from a marked starting point. The time is calculated from the initiation to the end of walking when the patient has reached the 25-foot mark. Scoring of this test is based on the average of two completed trials.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: 6 Minute Walk Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: 6 Minute Walk Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed by Bruno Blake in 1963, which is a performance-based evaluation of functional exercise capacity in subjects with chronic respiratory disease and heart failure, as well as other populations such as healthy older adults and people suffering from fibromyalgia and scleroderma. This functional test contains 6 items and measures the distance an individual is able to walk over a total of six minutes on a hard, flat surface.

Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed by Bruno Blake in 1963, which is a performance-based evaluation of functional exercise capacity in subjects with chronic respiratory disease and heart failure, as well as other populations such as healthy older adults and people suffering from fibromyalgia and scleroderma. This functional test contains 6 items and measures the distance an individual is able to walk over a total of six minutes on a hard, flat surface.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Symbol Digit Modalities Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Symbol Digit Modalities Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed by Aaron Smith in 1982, which is used to identify individuals with neurological impairment, as well as to assess divided attention, visual scanning and motor speed. This functional test measures the time to pair abstract symbols with specific numbers with a 90 second time limit. Scoring of this test is based on the total number of correctly coded items from 0-110 in 90 seconds.

Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed by Aaron Smith in 1982, which is used to identify individuals with neurological impairment, as well as to assess divided attention, visual scanning and motor speed. This functional test measures the time to pair abstract symbols with specific numbers with a 90 second time limit. Scoring of this test is based on the total number of correctly coded items from 0-110 in 90 seconds.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Rising From Floor Test Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Rising From Floor Test Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A timed function test created by Araujo et al. (2012) that measures the time taken and techniques utilized to sit and rise from the floor with the minimum amount of support as a predictor of overall health and life expectancy.

Concepts.longName: Rising From Floor Test Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A timed function test created by Araujo et al. (2012) that measures the time taken and techniques utilized to sit and rise from the floor with the minimum amount of support as a predictor of overall health and life expectancy.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Performance of the Upper Limb Module for DMD 2.0 Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Performance of the Upper Limb Module for DMD 2.0 Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A revised version of the Performance of the Upper Limb Module for DMD 1.2 Functional Test, which was developed by an international clinical outcomes group in 2011 to measure motor performance of the upper limb in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Functional tasks are subdivided into three dimensions that reflect disease progression from proximal to distal weakness, and from ambulatory to non-ambulatory.

Concepts.longName: Performance of the Upper Limb Module for DMD 2.0 Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A revised version of the Performance of the Upper Limb Module for DMD 1.2 Functional Test, which was developed by an international clinical outcomes group in 2011 to measure motor performance of the upper limb in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Functional tasks are subdivided into three dimensions that reflect disease progression from proximal to distal weakness, and from ambulatory to non-ambulatory.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Performance of the Upper Limb Module for DMD 1.2 Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Performance of the Upper Limb Module for DMD 1.2 Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A 22-item assessment scale developed by an international clinical outcomes group in 2011 to measure motor performance of the upper limb in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Functional tasks are subdivided into three dimensions that reflect disease progression from proximal to distal weakness, and from ambulatory to non-ambulatory.

Concepts.longName: Performance of the Upper Limb Module for DMD 1.2 Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A 22-item assessment scale developed by an international clinical outcomes group in 2011 to measure motor performance of the upper limb in patients with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). Functional tasks are subdivided into three dimensions that reflect disease progression from proximal to distal weakness, and from ambulatory to non-ambulatory.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Paced Auditory Serial Addition Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Paced Auditory Serial Addition Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed by DMA Gronwall et al in 1977 to assess auditory information processing speed and flexibility, as well as calculation ability. It is also used as a cognitive function test to evaluate sustained and divided attention. The test involves the presentation of single digits every 3 seconds and a study subject must add each new digit to the one immediately prior to it. Scoring of this test is based on the total number correct out of 60 possible answers.

Concepts.longName: Paced Auditory Serial Addition Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed by DMA Gronwall et al in 1977 to assess auditory information processing speed and flexibility, as well as calculation ability. It is also used as a cognitive function test to evaluate sustained and divided attention. The test involves the presentation of single digits every 3 seconds and a study subject must add each new digit to the one immediately prior to it. Scoring of this test is based on the total number correct out of 60 possible answers.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Paced Tapping Test Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Paced Tapping Test Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A cognitive test that is used to assess sensorimotor synchronization and timing of movement, where a subject produces a series of finger taps, at first in time with an external pacing stimulus and then continuing after the stimulus has ended.

Concepts.definition: A cognitive test that is used to assess sensorimotor synchronization and timing of movement, where a subject produces a series of finger taps, at first in time with an external pacing stimulus and then continuing after the stimulus has ended.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Nine-Hole Peg Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Nine-Hole Peg Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed by Mathiowetz et al in 1985 to measure unilateral finger dexterity to determine the extent of fine motor impairment in people experiencing difficulties with functional performance. This functional test requires the use of both dominant and non-dominant hands, and assesses fine motor and hand/eye coordination, as well as ability to follow simple directions. Scoring of this test is based on the average of 4 trials.

Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed by Mathiowetz et al in 1985 to measure unilateral finger dexterity to determine the extent of fine motor impairment in people experiencing difficulties with functional performance. This functional test requires the use of both dominant and non-dominant hands, and assesses fine motor and hand/eye coordination, as well as ability to follow simple directions. Scoring of this test is based on the average of 4 trials.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Montreal Cognitive Assessment Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Montreal Cognitive Assessment Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed by Ziad Nasreddine in 1996 to screen for mild cognitive dysfunction and impairment. This instrument assesses the following cognitive domains: attention and concentration, executive functions, memory, language, visuoconstructional skills, conceptual thinking, calculations, and orientation.

Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed by Ziad Nasreddine in 1996 to screen for mild cognitive dysfunction and impairment. This instrument assesses the following cognitive domains: attention and concentration, executive functions, memory, language, visuoconstructional skills, conceptual thinking, calculations, and orientation.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Mini-Mental State Examination 2 Standard Version Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Mini-Mental State Examination 2 Standard Version Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An updated version of the Mini-Mental State Examination, a brief, quantitative measure of cognitive status in adults, that was originally developed by Marshal Folstein, Susan Folstein and Paul McHugh (Journal of Psychiatric Research, 1975), where the overall difficulty and raw score range remain the same despite modifications to some tasks and replacement of some items.

Concepts.longName: Mini-Mental State Examination 2 Standard Version Functional Test
Concepts.definition: An updated version of the Mini-Mental State Examination, a brief, quantitative measure of cognitive status in adults, that was originally developed by Marshal Folstein, Susan Folstein and Paul McHugh (Journal of Psychiatric Research, 1975), where the overall difficulty and raw score range remain the same despite modifications to some tasks and replacement of some items.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Mini-Mental Status Exam

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Mini-Mental Status Exam
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized and structured interview originally developed by Marshal Folstein, Susan Folstein and Paul McHugh (Journal of Psychiatric Research, 1975), which is used to evaluate an individual's cognitive function.

Concepts.definition: A standardized and structured interview originally developed by Marshal Folstein, Susan Folstein and Paul McHugh (Journal of Psychiatric Research, 1975), which is used to evaluate an individual's cognitive function.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Hauser Ambulation Index Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Hauser Ambulation Index Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed by Hauser et al in 1983 to assess mobility by evaluating the time and degree of assistance required to walk 25 feet. This functional test is scored from 0 (asymptomatic; fully active) to 9 (restricted to wheelchair; unable to transfer self independently).

Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed by Hauser et al in 1983 to assess mobility by evaluating the time and degree of assistance required to walk 25 feet. This functional test is scored from 0 (asymptomatic; fully active) to 9 (restricted to wheelchair; unable to transfer self independently).

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Emotion Recognition Test Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Emotion Recognition Test Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized method for measuring visibly different facial movements that was developed by Ekman et al in 1976.

Concepts.definition: A standardized method for measuring visibly different facial movements that was developed by Ekman et al in 1976.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Controlled Oral Word Association Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Controlled Oral Word Association Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A test that measures the verbal fluency of an individual. This tool measures both semantic fluency and phonetic fluency.

Concepts.definition: A test that measures the verbal fluency of an individual. This tool measures both semantic fluency and phonetic fluency.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Brief Assessment of Cognition in Schizophrenia Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Brief Assessment of Cognition in Schizophrenia Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale developed by Keefe et al in 2004 to assess cognitive function and impairment in patients with schizophrenia. This instrument consists 6 tests in the following areas: verbal memory, working memory, motor speed, verbal fluency, attention, and executive function.

Concepts.longName: Brief Assessment of Cognition in Schizophrenia Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale developed by Keefe et al in 2004 to assess cognitive function and impairment in patients with schizophrenia. This instrument consists 6 tests in the following areas: verbal memory, working memory, motor speed, verbal fluency, attention, and executive function.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A standardized rating scale modified from A. Rey in 1964 and Ceffen et al in 1994, which is used to evaluate verbal learning and memory abilities in both children and adults. The questionnaire contains 36 items and assesses overall memory performance, immediate span of memory for words, acquisition rate, interference effects, and recognition.

Concepts.longName: Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A standardized rating scale modified from A. Rey in 1964 and Ceffen et al in 1994, which is used to evaluate verbal learning and memory abilities in both children and adults. The questionnaire contains 36 items and assesses overall memory performance, immediate span of memory for words, acquisition rate, interference effects, and recognition.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative Auditory Verbal Learning Test Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative Auditory Verbal Learning Test Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative's (ADNI) version of the Auditory Verbal Learning Test (AVLT Version A). This version is modified from A. Rey in 1964 and is used to evaluate verbal learning and memory abilities in both children and adults. The test format consists of a list of 15 words that the patient recalls during 5 separate trials. A second list with 15 new words is read and the patient must recall the words in one trial. Immediately following this task, the patient must recall the words from the first list; then recall them again 30 minutes later. The total number of words and intrusions is tallied for each trial.

Concepts.longName: Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative Auditory Verbal Learning Test Functional Test
Concepts.definition: The Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative's (ADNI) version of the Auditory Verbal Learning Test (AVLT Version A). This version is modified from A. Rey in 1964 and is used to evaluate verbal learning and memory abilities in both children and adults. The test format consists of a list of 15 words that the patient recalls during 5 separate trials. A second list with 15 new words is read and the patient must recall the words in one trial. Immediately following this task, the patient must recall the words from the first list; then recall them again 30 minutes later. The total number of words and intrusions is tallied for each trial.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Short Physical Performance Battery Version 1.2 Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Short Physical Performance Battery Version 1.2 Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Short Physical Performance Battery V1.2 (SPPB V1.2) (Guralnik JM, Ferrucci L, Pieper CF, Leveille SG, Markides KS, Ostir GV, Studenski S, Berkman LF, Wallace RB. Lower extremity function and subsequent disability: consistency across studies, predictive models, and value of gait speed alone compared with the short physical performance battery. J Gerontol A Biol Sci Med Sci 2000 April;55(4):M221-M231).

Concepts.longName: Short Physical Performance Battery Version 1.2 Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A standardized five-item 10-minute assessment tool, developed by Guralnik et al. 1994, that is used for the evaluation of lower extremity physical function and consists of three subtests, including standing balance, walking, and rising from a chair.

PermissibleValues.value: ROCKPORT ONE MILE WALK TEST V1.0
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Rockport One Mile Walk Test Version 1.0 Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Rockport One Mile Walk Test Version 1.0 Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Rockport One Mile Walk Test Version 1.0 (ROCKPORT ONE MILE WALK TEST V1.0) (Kline GM, Porcari JP, Hintermeister R, et. al. 1987. Estimation of VO2 Max from a one mile track walk, gender, age, and body weight. Medicine and Science in sports and Exercise. 19:253-59).

Concepts.longName: Rockport One Mile Walk Test Version 1.0 Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A submaximal fitness test, developed by Kline et al. in 1987, that utilizes the fastest time taken to walk one mile (T1), heart rate measured at the fourth quarter of the mile (HR1-4), sex (SEX; male = 1, female = 0), age in years (AGE), and body weight in pounds (WT) to estimate maximal oxygen consumption (VO2max) using the equation: VO2max = 6.9652 + (0.0091*WT) - (0.0257*AGE) + (0.5955*SEX) - (0.2240*T1) - (0.0115*HR1-4).

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Huntington's Disease Cognitive Assessment Battery Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Huntington's Disease Cognitive Assessment Battery Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Huntington's Disease Cognitive Assessment Battery (HD-CAB) (Copyright 2014 Monash University. All Rights Reserved. Stout, J.C. et al. HD-CAB: A cognitive assessment battery for clinical trials in Huntington's disease. Movement Disorders. 2014;29(10):1281-1288).

Concepts.longName: Huntington's Disease Cognitive Assessment Battery Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A set of six tests that were combined by Stout et al. in 2014 as an assessment tool for the effects of Huntington's disease treatment on cognition. The battery of tests, which include the Symbol Digit Modalities Test (SDMT), Emotion Recognition, Trail Making Test, Hopkins Verbal Learning Test (HVLT), Paced Tapping, and One Touch Stockings of Cambridge (OTS), cover a range of cognitive abilities known to decline in Huntington's disease, including attention, processing speed, visuospatial processing, timing, emotion processing, memory, and executive function.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Four Stair Descend Test Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Four Stair Descend Test Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A timed function test, one of a series of exercise testing modalities that were initially introduced in the 1960s, that measures functional mobility by assessing the time taken and techniques used to descend four standard-size stairs.

Concepts.longName: Four Stair Descend Test Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A timed function test, one of a series of exercise testing modalities that were initially introduced in the 1960s, that measures functional mobility by assessing the time taken and techniques used to descend four standard-size stairs.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Ten Meter Walk/Run Test Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Ten Meter Walk/Run Test Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A timed function test, one of a series of exercise testing modalities that were initially introduced in the 1960s, that assesses functional mobility by measuring walking or running speed in meters per second over ten meters.

Concepts.definition: A timed function test, one of a series of exercise testing modalities that were initially introduced in the 1960s, that assesses functional mobility by measuring walking or running speed in meters per second over ten meters.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Four Stair Ascend Test Functional Test

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Four Stair Ascend Test Functional Test
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A timed function test, one of a series of exercise testing modalities that were initially introduced in the 1960s, that measures functional mobility by assessing the time taken and techniques used to climb four standard-size stairs.

Concepts.longName: Four Stair Ascend Test Functional Test
Concepts.definition: A timed function test, one of a series of exercise testing modalities that were initially introduced in the 1960s, that measures functional mobility by assessing the time taken and techniques used to climb four standard-size stairs.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: An organizational header for concepts representing mostly abstract entities.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Terminology associated with the functional test domain categories of the Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium (CDISC) Standard Data Tabulation Model (SDTM).:A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.
